nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: The Trigger Moment
nodes.text: The door slams hard enough to shake the frame. Your co-parent storms into the room, holding an unpacked school bag. Your child watches from the hallway, frozen.

choices.label: Stay still and take one slow breath.
React immediately and raise your voice.
choices.text: “What is this now? Why are you slamming doors?”

choices.label: Send the child to their room gently.
choices.text: You turn and quietly tell the child: “Sweetie, give us a minute, okay?”

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: The Explosion
nodes.text: “I asked you ONE thing — ONE — and you still forgot to pack the homework folder! Do you understand how embarrassing this is for me?” Their voice is sharp, brittle.

choices.label: Use a grounding phrase.
choices.text: “I hear you're upset. Let’s talk about this without yelling.”

choices.label: Deflect responsibility.
choices.text: “It’s not my fault. Maybe check the bag before leaving the house.”

choices.label: Acknowledge the intensity, not the blame.
choices.text: “This sounds really stressful. Let’s slow down a second.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: The Turning Point
nodes.text: The co-parent exhales sharply, pacing. Their anger isn’t just about the folder — it’s about the whole week. You can feel the situation wobbling between repair or escalation.

choices.label: Offer a reset moment.
choices.text: “Let’s pause. Do you want a glass of water before we keep talking?”

choices.label: Push back on their tone.
choices.text: “You don’t get to talk to me like this. Calm down first.”

choices.label: Shift toward collaboration.
choices.text: “Let’s fix the morning routine so this doesn’t happen again.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: A Breath Before Act 2
nodes.text: The air eases just slightly. A crack in the storm — small, but enough to shift the direction.

choices.label: Continue to Act 2 — Emotional De-escalation
choices.text: You move carefully into the next phase.
